captions.text: You're in line at the grocery store when, uh oh,
someone sneezes on you.
The cold virus is sucked inside your lungs
and lands on a cell on your airway lining.
Every living thing on Earth is made of cells,
from the smallest one-celled bacteria
to the giant blue whale to you.
Each cell in your body is surrounded by a cell membrane,
a thick flexible layer made of fats and proteins,
that surrounds and protects the inner components.
It's semipermeable,
meaning that it lets some thing pass in and out
but blocks others.
The cell membrane is covered with tiny projections.
They all have functions,
like helping cells adhere to their neighbors
or binding to nutrients the cell will need.
Animal and plant cells have cell membranes.
Only plant cells have a cell wall,
which is made of rigid cellulose that gives the plant structure.
The virus cell that was sneezed into your lungs is sneaky.
Pretending to be a friend,
it attaches to a projection on the cell membrane,
and the cell brings it through the cell membrane and inside.
When the virus gets through,
the cell recognizes its mistake.
An enemy is inside!
Special enzymes arrive at the scene
and chop the virus to pieces.
They then send one of the pieces back
through the cell membrane,
where the cell displays it to warn neighboring cells
about the invader.
A nearby cell sees the warning
and immediately goes into action.
It needs to make antibodies,
proteins that will attack and kill
the invading virus.
This process starts in the nucleus.
The nucleus contains our DNA,
the blueprint that tells our cells how to make everything
our bodies need to function.
A certain section of our DNA contains instructions
that tell our cells how to make antibodies.
Enzymes in the nucleus find the right section of DNA,
then create a copy of these instructions,
called messenger RNA.
The messenger RNA leaves the nucleus to carry out its orders.
The messenger RNA travels to a ribosome.
There can be as many as 10 million ribosomes
in a human cell,
all studded along a ribbon-like structure
called the endoplasmic reticulum.
This ribosome reads the instructions from the nucleus.
It takes amino acids and links them together one by one
creating an antibody protein that will go fight the virus.
But before it can do that,
the antibody needs to leave the cell.
The antibody heads to the golgi apparatus.
Here, it's packed up for delivery outside the cell.
Enclosed in a bubble made of the same material as the cell membrane,
the golgi apparatus also gives the antibody directions,
telling it how to get to the edge of the cell.
When it gets there,
the bubble surrounding the antibody fuses to the cell membrane.
The cell ejects the antibody,
and it heads out to track down the virus.
The leftover bubble will be broken down
by the cell's lysosomes
and its pieces recycled over and over again.
Where did the cell get the energy to do all this?
That's the roll of the mitochondria.
To make energy, the mitochondria takes oxygen,
this is the only reason we breathe it,
and adds electrons from the food we eat
to make water molecules.
That process also creates a high energy molecule,
called ATP which the cell uses to power all of its parts.
Plant cells make energy a different way.
They have chloroplasts
that combine carbon dioxide and water
with light energy from the sun
to create oxygen and sugar,
a form of chemical energy.
All the parts of a cell have to work together
to keep things running smoothly,
and all the cells of your body have to work together
to keep you running smoothly.
That's a whole lot of cells.
Scientists think there are about 37 trillion of them.

title: Cell vs. virus: A battle for health - Shannon Stiles

comments.author: Brandon Burdett

comments.text:
By bodies, I'm assuming that you are referring to different people. All of 
your cells are labelled with something that marks them as yours. When you 
inject foreign antibodies into your own body, your body treats it like many 
other foreign pathogens/proteins. Your body will mount an immune response 
to those antibodies because your body deems it as not yours. This is why 
when you get injection of antibodies, you are often given adjuvants, things 
that suppress your immune system so that the system will let those 
antibodies pass without mounting an immune response.

comments.text:
Great video! HI guys, Math Utility here. We know math can be very 
challenging at times, especially for you High School students. Tons of 
homework, lots of tests to prepare for, we totally get it. That is where we 
step in. Math Utility is a 4 day old account, primarily focused on 
delivering our viewers with a easy to understand, less than 2 minute video 
about topics in Geometry and Algebra I that could be very hard to 
understand. 

If you ever need any help, or know of someone that does, PLEASE send them 
over to our page, not only for our sake, but for theirs too! They will gain 
a quick understanding of the topic in the video, and will go into that test 
or homework assignment a lot more confident in their ability. Come check us 
out, and refer us to your friends!

We take ANY recommendations on math based videos, and will do our absolute 
best to have those videos uploaded within 2 days!

Thank You and Have a Fantastic Day,
Your Math Utility Team﻿

comments.text:
Very accurate, with my recessive genotype, how would a low white cell count 
with an almost triple amount of anti-bodies respond to a virus? I been 
injected to the Swine-Flu disease via military and ever since, my anatomy 
has rendered me unable to contract any virus. Am I special, or is it a 
property of science that my violent subjections to foreign proteins the 
cause of survival to which I'm imune to everything? Please help, because 
I'm immune to almost everything, and I need to know why I'm so different. ﻿
comments.author: Wrex Rogers

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure I can contract HIV or STDS. But viruses like the cold or 
flu, so I guess I over-simplified on the first post. I'm not certain on the 
why my white blood cell is very low either. A doctor found this out taking 
my blood test during a physical required to work at Licking Memorial 
Hospital. Well thanks for your analysis, we've been back forth for a while 
now. Even though at first you came off as an ***, I see you're analytical 
and critical with detail. I can definitely appreciate that. So yeah, my 
question originated by the accuracy of the video of cells and viruses. I 
posted in hopes of hearing a response from the uploader, but your analysis 
is what makes me glad to be honest to people. I'd like to see some of your 
responses to other people sometime. I thought being a "special snowflake" 
was funny. Laterz! ^w^
comments.author: Wrex Rogers

comments.text:
How do you know that you're immune to everything lol, did you try to get 
yourself HIV or something. Everyone is almost immune to everything, our 
body is good in that way. A swollen lymph node indicates high level of 
immune activity because the lymph node is where you activate your adaptive 
immune cells that are specific to every single foreign pathogens. Although 
I don't really get why you can have high count of antibodies when your 
white blood cells are low in numbers.

comments.text:
I think this an excellent introductory cartoon for children. It's 
entertaining and carries the seeds of larger, more physiologically accurate 
explanations that can be added and integrated in later layers. I can't help 
but wonder why we don't get short, well illustrated and animated versions 
of these types of science videos in addition to cartoons, however. Is it 
not possible to do multimedia presentations of these concepts in short, 
abbreviated segments using more physiologically accurate images without 
being funded by pharmaceutical companies?﻿

comments.text:
*All living things are made of cells. In the human body, these highly 
efficient units are protected by layer upon layer of defense against icky 
invaders like the cold virus. Shannon Stiles takes a journey into the cell, 
introducing the microscopic arsenal of weapons and warriors that play a 
role in the battle for your health*﻿

comments.author: Jan Camus

comments.text:
A very elementary, but rather effective, video for the layman. Do note that 
the video very understandably (you have to cut the detail of somewhere) 
leaves out professional antigen presenting cells, the MHC complex, and the 
role of T-Cells and their formation in the thymus. Accordingly, the video 
implies that "normal" cells makes antibodies directly which really isn't 
the case as this is the job of humoral immunity through B cells. Just a 
small note for anyone wishing to follow up in more detail.﻿

comments.author: dboy270

comments.text:
I'm not a biologist, so if I'm wrong, please correct me, but...
1) there is no "virus cell"
2) as someone mentioned, RNA, including mRNA, uses uracil instead of thymine
3) not all ribosomes are on the surface of the endoplasmic reticulum
4) oxygen + protons = water, though electrons do come in as well (it's 
complicated)
5) plants get their energy exactly the same way, photosynthesis is for 
creating their own food (we have to get ours from them or from other 
animals)

PS: I'm writing this so that someone does not take the information in the 
video too literally. It's designed to introduce you into a subject. If 
you're studying for a test, textbook would probably be better.﻿
comments.author: Michal Pieter

comments.text: Good!﻿
